pull_request.title: Fix sorting in OGDSUserListing when members of a group are listed.
pull_request.body:
When listing users from a group, we join the `users` table with the `groups_users` table and we then need to make sure that columns are unambiguous (userid is in both tables). Before we had added the table designation in front of the column name for the sorting parameter, e.g. `users.userid`. Unfortunately this did not work, as the `sort_on` parameter [was simply dropped because the column was not recognised](https://github.com/4teamwork/opengever.core/blob/master/opengever/api/ogdslistingbase.py#L94-L95). If it had not been dropped it would have led to an error in SQL alchemy afterwards anyway.
Instead we now use a table statement to clearly define the sorting column.


Definition of Done: https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CHX4TW/pages/917562/

For [CA-4852]

pull_request.body:
_PR-Description: should contain all the information necessary for an outsider to understand the change without looking at the code or the issue!_

- _Why the change is necessary_
- _What the goal of the change is_
- _How change is achieved (e.g. design decisions)_
- _The author should advertise and sell the change in the PR body_

_Screenshot: whenever useful, but only as a visual aid._


Definition of Done: https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CHX4TW/pages/917562/

For [CA-XXXX]

## Checklist

_Everything has to be done/checked. Checked but not present means the author deemed it unnecessary._

- [ ] Changelog entry
- [ ] Link to issue (Jira or GitHub) and backlink in issue (Jira)

_Only applicable should be left and checked._

- Upgrade-Steps:
  - [ ] SQL Operations do not use imported model (see [docs](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/4TEAM/pages/994344994/Upgrade-Steps))
  - [ ] Make it deferrable if possible
  - [ ] Execute as much as possible conditionally
  - DB-Schema migration
    - [ ] All changes on a model (columns, etc) are included in a DB-schema migration.
    - [ ] Constraint names are shorter than 30 characters (`Oracle`)
- API change:
  - [ ] Documentation is updated
  - [ ] API Changelog entry (see [guide](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/4TEAM/pages/451248812/API+Changelog+Guidelines))
  - If breaking:
    - [ ] api-change label added
    - [ ] #delivery channel notified about breaking change
    - [ ] Scrum master is informed
- Bug fixed:
  - [ ] Resolved any Sentry issues caused by this bug
- New functionality:
  - [ ] for `document` also works for `mail`
  - [ ] for `task` also works for `forwarding`
- Further improvements needed:
  - [ ] Create follow-up stories and link them in the PR and Jira issue
- [ ] Change could impact client installations, client policies need to be adapted
- New translations
  - [ ] All msg-strings are unicode
- Change in schema definition:
  - [ ] If `missing_value` is specified, then `default` has to be set to the same value

commits.message:
Add `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint:

This API endpoint is used to prepare copying a dossier to a linked workspace.

It operates in two modes: Validation, or preparing an empty folder structure on
the teamraum side to upload documents to.

In validation mode, it checks that the given structure (subdossier(s) and
documents) satisfies all the constraints to be copied to a workspace. If not,
a detailed list of errors by object is returned.

In "prepare structure" mode, it will mirror the structure of the given
subdossier to teamraum by creating empty folders in the workspace, and
returning a list of documents, including their target folders that the client
should then upload them to.

The second stage ("prepare structure") does not perform validation again. It
assumes that the client validated the structure beforehand, and either
everything is ok, or the user selected "copy anyway", in which case some
individual document uploads will fail.

@copy-document-to-workspace: Also allow copying documents to workspace folders:

If a folder_uid is given, a document may now also be copied to the respective
workspace folder, instead of the workspace root. In order to accomplish this,
the `@upload-document-copy` endpoint now is also available on workspace folders.

OpengeverFixtureWithSolr: Isolate Solr data between tests:

In order to properly isolate Solr between tests, the data needs to be restored
to the 'fixture' backup that was created on layer setup.

Testing: Use PORT2 instead of PORT5 for Solr during tests:

The docker service layers that were added (msgconvert, weasyprint, etc..)
use ports 5-8 for their docker containers. Because Solr already uses PORT5
as well, this leads to occasional port conflicts on Jenkins.

Because the ports for the service layers are a nice sequence, we change the
Solr port instead (to PORT2, which is currently unused).

Testing: Make sure layer names don't start with the name of another layer:

The --layer flag of collective.xmltestreport / zope.testrunner greedily matches
layer names by default.

For this reason, when a layer name starts with a prefix that is itself the name
of another layer, we run into issues with bin/mtest because tests on that
layer will be run multiple times, may not be excluded as expected or may run
in parallel even though they shouldn't.
Add a functional Solr ZServer layer and base linked workspace tests on it.
Add tests for `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint.

Also allow `@upload-document-copy` on workspace folders:

This allows the frontend to also copy GEVER documents to workspace folders.

commits.message:
Bump docxcompose version to 1.3.6:

Fixes a bug where cached values for empty/absent docproperties weren't always
updated in the document, and therefore their placeholder values didn't get
replaced.
Preparing release 1.3.6
Back to development: 1.3.7

vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None:

This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to
XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty
<vt:lpwstr/> nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading
docproperties from a document, an empty <vt:lpwstr/> node was turned into
Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases
where a docproperty's value in the document's docProps/custom.xml was empty,
it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value
was skipped in update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with
empty string for those doc properties.

Merge pull request #84 from 4teamwork/lg/CA-4795/empty-docprops

vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None

pull_request.title: vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None
pull_request.body:
This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading docproperties from a document, an empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` node was turned into Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases where a docproperty's value in the document's `docProps/custom.xml` was empty, it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value was skipped in `update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with empty string for those doc properties, because in `update_all()` properties with a value of None simply [get skipped](https://github.com/4teamwork/docxcompose/blob/master/docxcompose/properties.py#L296-L298), and their cached value not updated (which is otherwise correct, because `None` is not a valid value for a doc property - it should always have a value, even if it's the empty string). 

For [CA-4795](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4795)

pull_request.title: Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties
pull_request.body:
Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties:

This includes the KuB fields `addressLine1` and `addressLine2` in DocProperties for addresses as `.address.extra_line_1` and `.address.extra_line_2` respectively.

---

KuB labels these `Adresszusatz 1` in the UI, and names them `addressLine1` in the API. That feels incorrect to me. In common usage, "adress line 1" is usually non-optional (and refers to the street + number), and "address line 2" is optional, and only to be supplied if the first line is not specific enough on its own.

The KuB usage seems different - these are always optional, and always to be used in _addition_ to "street + number". Therefore I named them `extra_line_...` to make it clear that these can't be substituted for any of the other fields, but should be included in addition to them.

For [CA-4703](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4703)

## Checklist

- [x] Changelog entry
- [x] Link to issue (Jira or GitHub) and backlink in issue (Jira)

pull_request.title: vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None
pull_request.body:
This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading docproperties from a document, an empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` node was turned into Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases where a docproperty's value in the document's `docProps/custom.xml` was empty, it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value was skipped in `update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with empty string for those doc properties.

pull_request.title: Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties.
pull_request.body:
Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties:

When serializing a KuB membership to DocProperties, this will also include the organization's phone number in `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number` (where [scope] may currently be `sender` or `recipient`).

A side effect of this is that when serializing an `organization` entity, its phone number is now exposed twice in DocProperties: Once in `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number` and once in `ogg.[scope.]phone.number`.

This is because the phone number is once included by the `KuBPhoneNumberDocPropertyProvider` at the upper, generic level (that exposes common properties in an entity type agnostic way), and once more by the `KuBOrganizationDocPropertyProvider` under `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number`, to be able to distinguish the org's phone number from the person's.

For [CA-4703](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4703)

Add tests for BaseDocPropertyProvider.

Add support for omitting app prefix in BaseDocPropertyProvider.get_properties():

When `with_app_prefix=False` is specified as a keyword argument, the properties
are still prefixed with a possible local prefix and default prefix, but not
with the app namespace ('ogg').

This allows for easier reuse of DocPropertyProviders to build composite
providers that delegate to other providers, and include their results (which
may also contain already nested namespaces).

Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties:

When serializing a KuB membership to DocProperties, this will also include the
organization's phone number in 'ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number'
(where [scope] may currently be 'sender' or 'recipient').

A side effect of this is that when serializing an 'organization' entity, its
phone number is now exposed twice in DocProperties: Once in
'ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number' and once in
'ogg.[scope.]phone.number'.

pull_request.title: Consider time zone when determining the end date of a dossier
pull_request.body:
When determining the end date for dossiers, the time zone was not taken into account. If a document was last modified on 10.10.22 at 00:15, therefore then the date 09.10. came out, because the modified datetime is stored as utc, and from this the date was generated. Now, when converting the datetime to a date, the local time zone is respected.

For [CA-4774]

Add `organization` column to OGDS user model:

This column is intended to track a user's organization in a simpler way than
the existing directorate and department columns.

In order to be populated, it will need to be mapped in the LDAP schema to an
AD/LDAP attribute first, with a public_name of 'organization'. Then it will be

Cleanup: Reformat and sort User.column_names_to_sync.

Add `display_name` column to OGDS user model:

The LDAP/AD attributes 'displayName' or 'cn' are sometimes
mapped to the 'fullname' property. This is especially the case for customers
that actively manage the display names of their users, e.g. to also contain
the user's department or their role.

If it exists, we store it in OGDS in the display_name column. This is therefore
a customer-controlled display name, and different from the fullname we build
in the User.fullname() method by concatenating first and last name.
OGDS auth plugin: Use OGDS `display_name` as the `fullname` member property.

Fix how we access SA RowProxy results in OGDS auth plugin:

When using SQLAlchemy Core queries instead of the ORM, the returned results
aren't ORM mapped instances, but RowProxy objects that look and act a lot
like tuples:

(u'Peter', u'Archivar', u'peter.archivar', None, u'info@4teamwork.ch')

Usually, the returned values are exactly in the order of the columns in the
SELECT statement, which is why it's tempting to jsut consider them a tuple
in the same order as the selected columns, and unpack the values that way.

However, if a column appears more than once in a SELECT statement, the
(identical) return value will not be repeated in the RowProxy result, which
is then shorter than the list of selected columns, throwing the whole order
off.

Instead, the RowProxy object also supports dictionary access by using the
column name as the key, which makes access to the column results unambiguous
and lets us avoid that whole ordered sequence matching dance.

pull_request.title: Add `display_name` column to OGDS user model
pull_request.body:
The LDAP/AD attributes `displayName` or `cn` are sometimes mapped to the `fullname` property. This is especially the case for customers that actively manage the display names of their users, e.g. to also contain the user's department or their role.

If it exists, we store it in OGDS in the `display_name` column. This is therefore a customer-controlled display name, and different from the fullname we build in the `User.fullname()` method by concatenating first and last name.

With that display ending up in the `fullname` property, Plone will use it e.g. when searching for users in the sharing tab, or to display it in the personal tools menu.

Also contains a bugfix for accessing SQLAlchemy RowProxy results.

For [CA-4734](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4734)

pull_request.title: Fix sorting in OGDSUserListing when members of a group are listed.
pull_request.body:
When listing users from a group, we join the `users` table with the `groups_users` table and we then need to make sure that columns are unambiguous (userid is in both tables). Before we had added the table designation in front of the column name for the sorting parameter, e.g. `users.userid`. Unfortunately this did not work, as the `sort_on` parameter [was simply dropped because the column was not recognised](https://github.com/4teamwork/opengever.core/blob/master/opengever/api/ogdslistingbase.py#L94-L95). If it had not been dropped it would have led to an error in SQL alchemy afterwards anyway.
Instead we now use a table statement to clearly define the sorting column.


Definition of Done: https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CHX4TW/pages/917562/

commits.message:
Add `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint:

This API endpoint is used to prepare copying a dossier to a linked workspace.

It operates in two modes: Validation, or preparing an empty folder structure on
the teamraum side to upload documents to.

In validation mode, it checks that the given structure (subdossier(s) and
documents) satisfies all the constraints to be copied to a workspace. If not,
a detailed list of errors by object is returned.

In "prepare structure" mode, it will mirror the structure of the given
subdossier to teamraum by creating empty folders in the workspace, and
returning a list of documents, including their target folders that the client
should then upload them to.

The second stage ("prepare structure") does not perform validation again. It
assumes that the client validated the structure beforehand, and either
everything is ok, or the user selected "copy anyway", in which case some
individual document uploads will fail.

@copy-document-to-workspace: Also allow copying documents to workspace folders:

If a folder_uid is given, a document may now also be copied to the respective
workspace folder, instead of the workspace root. In order to accomplish this,
the `@upload-document-copy` endpoint now is also available on workspace folders.

OpengeverFixtureWithSolr: Isolate Solr data between tests:

In order to properly isolate Solr between tests, the data needs to be restored
to the 'fixture' backup that was created on layer setup.

Testing: Use PORT2 instead of PORT5 for Solr during tests:

The docker service layers that were added (msgconvert, weasyprint, etc..)
use ports 5-8 for their docker containers. Because Solr already uses PORT5
as well, this leads to occasional port conflicts on Jenkins.

Because the ports for the service layers are a nice sequence, we change the
Solr port instead (to PORT2, which is currently unused).

Testing: Make sure layer names don't start with the name of another layer:

The --layer flag of collective.xmltestreport / zope.testrunner greedily matches
layer names by default.

For this reason, when a layer name starts with a prefix that is itself the name
of another layer, we run into issues with bin/mtest because tests on that
layer will be run multiple times, may not be excluded as expected or may run
in parallel even though they shouldn't.
Add a functional Solr ZServer layer and base linked workspace tests on it.
Add tests for `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint.

Also allow `@upload-document-copy` on workspace folders:

This allows the frontend to also copy GEVER documents to workspace folders.

In order to properly isolate Solr between tests, the data needs to be restored

pull_request.title: Some small fixes in the dossier export script after first productive run.
pull_request.body:

Add `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint:

This API endpoint is used to prepare copying a dossier to a linked workspace.

It operates in two modes: Validation, or preparing an empty folder structure on
the teamraum side to upload documents to.

In validation mode, it checks that the given structure (subdossier(s) and
documents) satisfies all the constraints to be copied to a workspace. If not,
a detailed list of errors by object is returned.

In "prepare structure" mode, it will mirror the structure of the given
subdossier to teamraum by creating empty folders in the workspace, and
returning a list of documents, including their target folders that the client
should then upload them to.

The second stage ("prepare structure") does not perform validation again. It
assumes that the client validated the structure beforehand, and either
everything is ok, or the user selected "copy anyway", in which case some
individual document uploads will fail.
WIP

Preparing release 1.3.6
Back to development: 1.3.7

vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None:

This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to
XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty
<vt:lpwstr/> nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading
docproperties from a document, an empty <vt:lpwstr/> node was turned into
Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases
where a docproperty's value in the document's docProps/custom.xml was empty,
it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value
was skipped in update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with
empty string for those doc properties.

Merge pull request #84 from 4teamwork/lg/CA-4795/empty-docprops

vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None

pull_request.title: vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None
pull_request.body:
This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading docproperties from a document, an empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` node was turned into Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases where a docproperty's value in the document's `docProps/custom.xml` was empty, it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value was skipped in `update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with empty string for those doc properties, because in `update_all()` properties with a value of None simply [get skipped](https://github.com/4teamwork/docxcompose/blob/master/docxcompose/properties.py#L296-L298), and their cached value not updated (which is otherwise correct, because `None` is not a valid value for a doc property - it should always have a value, even if it's the empty string). 

For [CA-4795](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4795)

pull_request.title: Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties
pull_request.body:
Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties:

This includes the KuB fields `addressLine1` and `addressLine2` in DocProperties for addresses as `.address.extra_line_1` and `.address.extra_line_2` respectively.

---

KuB labels these `Adresszusatz 1` in the UI, and names them `addressLine1` in the API. That feels incorrect to me. In common usage, "adress line 1" is usually non-optional (and refers to the street + number), and "address line 2" is optional, and only to be supplied if the first line is not specific enough on its own.

The KuB usage seems different - these are always optional, and always to be used in _addition_ to "street + number". Therefore I named them `extra_line_...` to make it clear that these can't be substituted for any of the other fields, but should be included in addition to them.

For [CA-4703](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4703)

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases where a docproperty's value in the document's `docProps/custom.xml` was empty, it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value was skipped in `update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with empty string for those doc properties.

pull_request.title: Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties.
pull_request.body:
Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties:

When serializing a KuB membership to DocProperties, this will also include the organization's phone number in `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number` (where [scope] may currently be `sender` or `recipient`).

A side effect of this is that when serializing an `organization` entity, its phone number is now exposed twice in DocProperties: Once in `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number` and once in `ogg.[scope.]phone.number`.

This is because the phone number is once included by the `KuBPhoneNumberDocPropertyProvider` at the upper, generic level (that exposes common properties in an entity type agnostic way), and once more by the `KuBOrganizationDocPropertyProvider` under `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number`, to be able to distinguish the org's phone number from the person's.

For [CA-4703](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4703)

_PR-Description: should contain all the information necessary for an outsider to understand the change without looking at the code or the issue!_

- _Why the change is necessary_
- _What the goal of the change is_
- _How change is achieved (e.g. design decisions)_
- _The author should advertise and sell the change in the PR body_

Definition of Done: https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CHX4TW/pages/917562/

_Everything has to be done/checked. Checked but not present means the author deemed it unnecessary._

- [ ] Link to issue (Jira or GitHub) and backlink in issue (Jira)

_Only applicable should be left and checked._

- Upgrade-Steps:
  - [ ] SQL Operations do not use imported model (see [docs](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/4TEAM/pages/994344994/Upgrade-Steps))
  - [ ] Make it deferrable if possible
  - [ ] Execute as much as possible conditionally
  - DB-Schema migration
    - [ ] All changes on a model (columns, etc) are included in a DB-schema migration.
    - [ ] Constraint names are shorter than 30 characters (`Oracle`)
- API change:
  - [ ] Documentation is updated
  - [ ] API Changelog entry (see [guide](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/4TEAM/pages/451248812/API+Changelog+Guidelines))
  - If breaking:
    - [ ] api-change label added
    - [ ] #delivery channel notified about breaking change
    - [ ] Scrum master is informed
- Bug fixed:

- New functionality:
  - [ ] for `document` also works for `mail`
  - [ ] for `task` also works for `forwarding`
- Further improvements needed:

- [ ] Change could impact client installations, client policies need to be adapted
- New translations

- Change in schema definition:
  - [ ] If `missing_value` is specified, then `default` has to be set to the same value

commits.message:
Add support for omitting app prefix in BaseDocPropertyProvider.get_properties():

When `with_app_prefix=False` is specified as a keyword argument, the properties
are still prefixed with a possible local prefix and default prefix, but not
with the app namespace ('ogg').

This allows for easier reuse of DocPropertyProviders to build composite
providers that delegate to other providers, and include their results (which
may also contain already nested namespaces).

pull_request.title: Consider time zone when determining the end date of a dossier
pull_request.body:
When determining the end date for dossiers, the time zone was not taken into account. If a document was last modified on 10.10.22 at 00:15, therefore then the date 09.10. came out, because the modified datetime is stored as utc, and from this the date was generated. Now, when converting the datetime to a date, the local time zone is respected.

For [CA-4774]

the existing directorate and department columns.

AD/LDAP attribute first, with a public_name of 'organization'. Then it will be
synced to OGDS.

Add `organization` column to OGDS user model:

This column is intended to track a user's organization in a simpler way than
the existing directorate and department columns.

In order to be populated, it will need to be mapped in the LDAP schema to an
AD/LDAP attribute first, with a public_name of 'organization'. Then it will be
synced to OGDS.
Cleanup: Reformat and sort User.column_names_to_sync.

Add `display_name` column to OGDS user model:

The LDAP/AD attributes 'displayName' or 'cn' are sometimes
mapped to the 'fullname' property. This is especially the case for customers
that actively manage the display names of their users, e.g. to also contain
the user's department or their role.

If it exists, we store it in OGDS in the display_name column. This is therefore
a customer-controlled display name, and different from the fullname we build
in the User.fullname() method by concatenating first and last name.
OGDS auth plugin: Use OGDS `display_name` as the `fullname` member property.

Fix how we access SA RowProxy results in OGDS auth plugin:

When using SQLAlchemy Core queries instead of the ORM, the returned results
aren't ORM mapped instances, but RowProxy objects that look and act a lot
like tuples:

(u'Peter', u'Archivar', u'peter.archivar', None, u'info@4teamwork.ch')

Usually, the returned values are exactly in the order of the columns in the
SELECT statement, which is why it's tempting to jsut consider them a tuple
in the same order as the selected columns, and unpack the values that way.

However, if a column appears more than once in a SELECT statement, the
(identical) return value will not be repeated in the RowProxy result, which
is then shorter than the list of selected columns, throwing the whole order
off.

Instead, the RowProxy object also supports dictionary access by using the
column name as the key, which makes access to the column results unambiguous
and lets us avoid that whole ordered sequence matching dance.

pull_request.title: Add `display_name` column to OGDS user model
pull_request.body:
The LDAP/AD attributes `displayName` or `cn` are sometimes mapped to the `fullname` property. This is especially the case for customers that actively manage the display names of their users, e.g. to also contain the user's department or their role.

If it exists, we store it in OGDS in the `display_name` column. This is therefore a customer-controlled display name, and different from the fullname we build in the `User.fullname()` method by concatenating first and last name.

With that display ending up in the `fullname` property, Plone will use it e.g. when searching for users in the sharing tab, or to display it in the personal tools menu.

Also contains a bugfix for accessing SQLAlchemy RowProxy results.

For [CA-4734](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4734)

pull_request.title: Fix sorting in OGDSUserListing when members of a group are listed.
pull_request.body:
When listing users from a group, we join the `users` table with the `groups_users` table and we then need to make sure that columns are unambiguous (userid is in both tables). Before we had added the table designation in front of the column name for the sorting parameter, e.g. `users.userid`. Unfortunately this did not work, as the `sort_on` parameter [was simply dropped because the column was not recognised](https://github.com/4teamwork/opengever.core/blob/master/opengever/api/ogdslistingbase.py#L94-L95). If it had not been dropped it would have led to an error in SQL alchemy afterwards anyway.
Instead we now use a table statement to clearly define the sorting column.


Definition of Done: https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CHX4TW/pages/917562/

commits.message:
Add `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint:

This API endpoint is used to prepare copying a dossier to a linked workspace.

It operates in two modes: Validation, or preparing an empty folder structure on
the teamraum side to upload documents to.

In validation mode, it checks that the given structure (subdossier(s) and
documents) satisfies all the constraints to be copied to a workspace. If not,
a detailed list of errors by object is returned.

In "prepare structure" mode, it will mirror the structure of the given
subdossier to teamraum by creating empty folders in the workspace, and
returning a list of documents, including their target folders that the client
should then upload them to.

The second stage ("prepare structure") does not perform validation again. It
assumes that the client validated the structure beforehand, and either
everything is ok, or the user selected "copy anyway", in which case some
individual document uploads will fail.

@copy-document-to-workspace: Also allow copying documents to workspace folders:

If a folder_uid is given, a document may now also be copied to the respective
workspace folder, instead of the workspace root. In order to accomplish this,
the `@upload-document-copy` endpoint now is also available on workspace folders.

OpengeverFixtureWithSolr: Isolate Solr data between tests:

In order to properly isolate Solr between tests, the data needs to be restored
to the 'fixture' backup that was created on layer setup.

Testing: Use PORT2 instead of PORT5 for Solr during tests:

The docker service layers that were added (msgconvert, weasyprint, etc..)
use ports 5-8 for their docker containers. Because Solr already uses PORT5
as well, this leads to occasional port conflicts on Jenkins.

Because the ports for the service layers are a nice sequence, we change the
Solr port instead (to PORT2, which is currently unused).

Testing: Make sure layer names don't start with the name of another layer:

The --layer flag of collective.xmltestreport / zope.testrunner greedily matches
layer names by default.

For this reason, when a layer name starts with a prefix that is itself the name
of another layer, we run into issues with bin/mtest because tests on that
layer will be run multiple times, may not be excluded as expected or may run
in parallel even though they shouldn't.
Add a functional Solr ZServer layer and base linked workspace tests on it.
Add tests for `@prepare-copy-dossier-to-workspace` endpoint.

Also allow `@upload-document-copy` on workspace folders:

This allows the frontend to also copy GEVER documents to workspace folders.

Add support for omitting app prefix in BaseDocPropertyProvider.get_properties():

When `with_app_prefix=False` is specified as a keyword argument, the properties
are still prefixed with a possible local prefix and default prefix, but not
with the app namespace ('ogg').

This allows for easier reuse of DocPropertyProviders to build composite
providers that delegate to other providers, and include their results (which
may also contain already nested namespaces).

Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties:

When serializing a KuB membership to DocProperties, this will also include the
organization's phone number in 'ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number'
(where [scope] may currently be 'sender' or 'recipient').

A side effect of this is that when serializing an 'organization' entity, its
phone number is now exposed twice in DocProperties: Once in
'ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number' and once in
'ogg.[scope.]phone.number'.

Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties:

This includes the KuB fields `addressLine1` and `addressLine2` in DocProperties
for addresses as `.address.extra_line_1` and `.address.extra_line_2`
respectively.

commits.message:
Bump docxcompose version to 1.3.6:

Fixes a bug where cached values for empty/absent docproperties weren't always
updated in the document, and therefore their placeholder values didn't get
replaced.
Preparing release 1.3.6
Back to development: 1.3.7

vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None:

This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to
XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty
<vt:lpwstr/> nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading
docproperties from a document, an empty <vt:lpwstr/> node was turned into
Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases
where a docproperty's value in the document's docProps/custom.xml was empty,
it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value
was skipped in update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with
empty string for those doc properties.

Merge pull request #84 from 4teamwork/lg/CA-4795/empty-docprops

vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None

pull_request.title: vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None
pull_request.body:
This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading docproperties from a document, an empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` node was turned into Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases where a docproperty's value in the document's `docProps/custom.xml` was empty, it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value was skipped in `update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with empty string for those doc properties, because in `update_all()` properties with a value of None simply [get skipped](https://github.com/4teamwork/docxcompose/blob/master/docxcompose/properties.py#L296-L298), and their cached value not updated (which is otherwise correct, because `None` is not a valid value for a doc property - it should always have a value, even if it's the empty string). 

For [CA-4795](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4795)

pull_request.title: Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties
pull_request.body:
Include extra address lines from KuB contacts in DocProperties:

This includes the KuB fields `addressLine1` and `addressLine2` in DocProperties for addresses as `.address.extra_line_1` and `.address.extra_line_2` respectively.

---

KuB labels these `Adresszusatz 1` in the UI, and names them `addressLine1` in the API. That feels incorrect to me. In common usage, "adress line 1" is usually non-optional (and refers to the street + number), and "address line 2" is optional, and only to be supplied if the first line is not specific enough on its own.

The KuB usage seems different - these are always optional, and always to be used in _addition_ to "street + number". Therefore I named them `extra_line_...` to make it clear that these can't be substituted for any of the other fields, but should be included in addition to them.

For [CA-4703](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4703)

pull_request.title: vt2value(): Convert empty <vt:lpwstr/> nodes to empty string instead of None
pull_request.body:
This fixes an asymmetry in how values get converted from Python data types to XML VTs, and vice versa. While empty Python strings are turned into empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` nodes, the same was not true the other way round: When reading docproperties from a document, an empty `<vt:lpwstr/>` node was turned into Python `None`.

This asymmetry caused a bug when updating cached docproperty values: In cases where a docproperty's value in the document's `docProps/custom.xml` was empty, it was parsed to Python `None` and therefore the update of the cached value was skipped in `update_all().

That lead to placeholder values in the document never getting replaced with empty string for those doc properties.

organization's phone number in 'ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number'
(where [scope] may currently be 'sender' or 'recipient').

A side effect of this is that when serializing an 'organization' entity, its

pull_request.title: Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties.
pull_request.body:
Include KuB organization phone number in membership docproperties:

When serializing a KuB membership to DocProperties, this will also include the organization's phone number in `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number` (where [scope] may currently be `sender` or `recipient`).

A side effect of this is that when serializing an `organization` entity, its phone number is now exposed twice in DocProperties: Once in `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number` and once in `ogg.[scope.]phone.number`.

This is because the phone number is once included by the `KuBPhoneNumberDocPropertyProvider` at the upper, generic level (that exposes common properties in an entity type agnostic way), and once more by the `KuBOrganizationDocPropertyProvider` under `ogg.[scope].organization.phone.number`, to be able to distinguish the org's phone number from the person's.

For [CA-4703](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4703)

commits.message:
Add support for omitting app prefix in BaseDocPropertyProvider.get_properties():

When `with_app_prefix=False` is specified as a keyword argument, the properties
are still prefixed with a possible local prefix and default prefix, but not
with the app namespace ('ogg').

This allows for easier reuse of DocPropertyProviders to build composite
providers that delegate to other providers, and include their results (which
may also contain already nested namespaces).

pull_request.title: Consider time zone when determining the end date of a dossier
pull_request.body:
When determining the end date for dossiers, the time zone was not taken into account. If a document was last modified on 10.10.22 at 00:15, therefore then the date 09.10. came out, because the modified datetime is stored as utc, and from this the date was generated. Now, when converting the datetime to a date, the local time zone is respected.

For [CA-4774]

Add `organization` column to OGDS user model:

This column is intended to track a user's organization in a simpler way than

AD/LDAP attribute first, with a public_name of 'organization'. Then it will be

Cleanup: Reformat and sort User.column_names_to_sync.

Add `display_name` column to OGDS user model:

The LDAP/AD attributes 'displayName' or 'cn' are sometimes
mapped to the 'fullname' property. This is especially the case for customers
that actively manage the display names of their users, e.g. to also contain
the user's department or their role.

If it exists, we store it in OGDS in the display_name column. This is therefore
a customer-controlled display name, and different from the fullname we build
in the User.fullname() method by concatenating first and last name.
OGDS auth plugin: Use OGDS `display_name` as the `fullname` member property.

Fix how we access SA RowProxy results in OGDS auth plugin:

When using SQLAlchemy Core queries instead of the ORM, the returned results
aren't ORM mapped instances, but RowProxy objects that look and act a lot
like tuples:

(u'Peter', u'Archivar', u'peter.archivar', None, u'info@4teamwork.ch')

Usually, the returned values are exactly in the order of the columns in the
SELECT statement, which is why it's tempting to jsut consider them a tuple
in the same order as the selected columns, and unpack the values that way.

However, if a column appears more than once in a SELECT statement, the
(identical) return value will not be repeated in the RowProxy result, which
is then shorter than the list of selected columns, throwing the whole order
off.

Instead, the RowProxy object also supports dictionary access by using the
column name as the key, which makes access to the column results unambiguous
and lets us avoid that whole ordered sequence matching dance.

pull_request.title: Add `display_name` column to OGDS user model
pull_request.body:
The LDAP/AD attributes `displayName` or `cn` are sometimes mapped to the `fullname` property. This is especially the case for customers that actively manage the display names of their users, e.g. to also contain the user's department or their role.

If it exists, we store it in OGDS in the `display_name` column. This is therefore a customer-controlled display name, and different from the fullname we build in the `User.fullname()` method by concatenating first and last name.

With that display ending up in the `fullname` property, Plone will use it e.g. when searching for users in the sharing tab, or to display it in the personal tools menu.

Also contains a bugfix for accessing SQLAlchemy RowProxy results.

For [CA-4734](https://4teamwork.atlassian.net/browse/CA-4734)

    - [x] All changes on a model (columns, etc) are included in a DB-schema migration.
    - [x] Constraint names are shorter than 30 characters (`Oracle`)

commits.message:
Add users.object_sid column to OGDS:

Once the OGDS auth plugin is used and the ActiveDirectoryMultiPlugin is
removed, we need to store the objectSid in OGDS for the OneOffixx integration
to still work.
Expose `objectSid` property via OGDS auth plugin.
